reviewText:
FlatOut was released on November 5, 2004 for both Windows and Consoles. My first impressions of the game were also back then. The game was fun. But now, it can only be played for nostalgia. I suggest you pick it up on a sale.

I said that the game was fun because there are better games out there that you can buy. This game made a good start for the derby racing game and started a future for FlatOut series. I still find it amazing how the driver just flies out of the window during big crash. The gave is hilarious especially if you play with friends. But I am not too sure if the game servers are even running. I know you can play with friends via some LAN programs or even HOTSEAT. It's a good game to have fun with.

As in any racing game there must be music in this one. It has a decent soundtrack for the time of release, but I have personally never heard those bands in my life before or after. I do not dislike the soundtrack but I think it could have been much better. The rest of the sound effects seem fine and nothing particular caught my eye( or more like ear).

2004 was a big year for very good looking games. This game didn't do too bad compared to big fish around that time. Car detail is good. The detail of the maps is good as well. Human rag dolls are a bit on the low side, but they are not that important. Overall, I am still very happy with the graphics to the current time.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=349808821
Controls and overall steering is a bit funny. I take it that's because the game was made for consoles too. There are not many buttons to press, but powerful steering can ruin your race.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=350923568
There are a few things, of course, that I quite hate about FlatOut. First thing is AI. It's so straight forward that it's actually not fun playing against computer. All it wants is to reach the finish line. I can also add that AI drives in the best possible way and will not crash. All other reasons add up to the first one. Because the AI drives really well, one mistake on the map could mean that you have lost your lead, quite probably for the rest of the match. And the last thing is that in my opinion the cars get damaged way too fast even without actually crashing into anything. But the end of the match you will end up having engine on fire, 2 car seats with human and skeleton of the car.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=350923322
Re-playability is low in my opinion, because you can just play other better games with the same name.

So in overall, I think this game (without considering the rest of the series at least) is quite good. I would recommend it simply because it's really fun. Not everywhere you can send the driver flying out.

reviewText:
A classic title from Bugbear Entertainment, FlatOut 1 is a racing game where you race scrapped-up derby cars around some tracks, to win, like any other racing game. However, unlike more realistic titles on Steam, this game seems to play more around dirty racing, such as slamming into your opponents, ramming them or pushing them into telephone poles.
Flatout doesn't take itself seriously, however, with the special events. I won't spoil them all, but they include such things as darts and a high jump. With your driver's body. Yeah, it was one of the first racing games to incoporate ragdoll physics and it plays this for laughs, especially when, if faced with a hard enough impact, your driver just FLIES out of the car.
Xbox controller support is okay, and it's a title that feels like it should be played with one. It's hardly taxing on modern hardware, and it runs pretty smooothly on laptops.
Honestly, give it a try, it's pretty enjoyable for the price!

reviewText:
While this game is very fun, it does have it fair share of problems. In some ways it feels a bit dated, but at the same time it holds up quite well. Which is not that surprising for a game that came out in 2005.

The controls really make and break this game. They are very floaty and extremely clunky. It basically feel like you're controlling a jetski in rough waters. When on tarmac, it feels good. You can drift around corners and speed through light curves and it feels like a great arcade racer. When you drive on snow and off-road on the other hand, you're sliding all over the place and have little to no control. Almost slowing down completely before big corners in order to handle them. And the AI cars will drift through like zen masters.
Which is another problem with this game. The AI. There's not much rubberbanding in this game. If one of the AI cars end up ahead of the pack, then their perfect path finding will leave you in the dust. You can never catch up. I had the fastest car with all upgrades, and they still sped ahead of me. This game is about crashing your opponents to get ahead, and then keep the lead. And if you crash yourself, you're forced to a 4 second slow-mo crash sequence, and when it ends you're put back quite a while. Usually last place. There's also a reset button. It works when prompted, and some other times as well. When you've been pushed off track and facing the wrong way though, it will most likely not work. You don't decide when to reset, Flatout does.

But when it all comes together (usually the tarmac tracks) this game is incredibly fun. But the other aggravations kept me from finishing this game. I beat the bronze and silver tracks, but I had to give up at the gold tracks. After resetting a track 20 times because the AI kept using the PIT maneuver to turn me the wrong way, I gave up. That's where the fun ended for me. But for the price and for the hours I put in, I can't complain. I will recommend this game, but be aware that it definitely has its shortcomings. But then again, it's also a 9 year old game.

reviewText:
This is a good example of a game that just doesn't know what it wants to be; the racing aspects of it actively contradict the demolition aspects, making it downright painful to play at times. All of the modes offered each somehow find a way to sap all of the fun out of flinging yourself from a moving vehicle.

Graphics: The cars and terrain look decent enough for 2004; I'd even go as far as to say the damage effects look good. The skybox texture and the background look like they came out of the '90s, however. There is an issue with models and textures not covering the full extent of their physics, creating invisible walls or bits of physics objects. The UI is abominable and after extended play it can begin warping itself around the world; it's difficult to explain, but it appears that physics are applied to the UI and it can glitch out, causing display issues.

Sound: The sound effects, particularly the car sounds, seem very budget and hollow, as if they were recorded on a $20 tape recorder from the 80's. The soundtrack itself though, is actually pretty good; most of the tracks fit the game well enough.

Gameplay: Your driver seems only too eager to launch himself through the windshield at the slightest brush from a sapling. Sure, it's funny the first couple of times, but when it gets right down to it, this game's poor physics and driver launching feature get in the way of both racing and, to a slightly lesser extent, the Bonus" modes (which include a counterintuitive demolition derby in which you keep your car from getting smashed
date: and things like darts and bowling which utilize your driver being launched from the vehicle). The vehicle customization is scant and performance options are as vague as those of the Need for Speed games of the era.\n\nConclusion: The main selling point of FlatOut proves to be little more than a tacked on gimmick to what is ultimately an average racer that seems to have assigned itself the task of trying to make losing funner and easier. If that sounds appealing to you then by all means go for it

reviewText:
Utterly disappointing.

I seriously cannot recommend this at all. This game just flops, specially compared to its successor. Ignore this and get FlatOut 2 instead.

Flaws:
• The cars feel weightless. You barely nudge a curb going 15 and your car just tumbles. You slam into another car and it doesn't really feel like you've done anything to it.
• Cars have no grip/traction, you seem to be constantly sliding along. This would be fine on snowy tracks, but not on every track. Braking basically has no effect, trying to slow down before a hairpin turn and NOPE! just keep on sliding off the course!
• Courses are very bland. They are wide and empty feeling with no character to them. Theres also very little in the way of different paths/shortcuts.
• You get flung from your car if you barely tap anything.. most of the time. The game is really inconsistent as to what makes you get flung out. Barely scrap a sign? AWAY YOU GO! Slam head on to another car? Nah, you're fine!
• Its a Demolition game.. WHERE I ACTIVELY DO NOT WANT TO CRASH, EVER. With how easy it is to be tossed out of your car, theres no point in going after the other racers. You get boost for crashing into things, but it also increases your odds of being thrown from your car, and the fact most things you can break to get boost are also very heavy when hit and will slow you down. Boosting is also something you'll only use to correct coming out of a turn, because going to fast and barely scraping something (and one time nothing at all) will send you flying!
• If you drive ever so slightly off the course, even though you can easily correct yourself and get back on, the game will nag you to reset, often respawning you behind everyone else! With how slippery your car handles, this is more common than it should be.
• The sound design is poor.. very poor. With how amazing it was in the 2nd game, I truly was surprised how crummy it is here.  There are almost no sounds for hitting things. Your tires are next to silent, with how slippery the cars already feel, the lack of sound makes the cars feel like they are floating. The engines sound weak, like you are driving a go-kart or lawn mower.
• Unsatisfying driving. Managing to get a perfect run on a track felt more like a test of patience than skill.
• Upgrades do nothing, atleast they feel that way. My thinking was to upgrade my tires and suspension to have better grip. Well it did nothing at all, the car was just and slidey as ever. You often feel like your car is under powered compared to the computer. Eventually after buying a few upgrades you can beat'em easily, even though the upgrades feel like they've done nothing at all to improve your car. You just suddenly starting keeping pace with the computer. There was no noticable increase in speed, durability, grip or anything.

The few Pros it has:
• The cars look nice again, being mostly muscle cars and having a nice demo derby look to them.... Now if they only sounded like muscle cars.
• Music seems a bit better than the 2nd and there was a noticable amount of female vocals.
• My controller worked on the menus! Not the way I would of liked it to, but it worked fine enough.

While its not the worst racing game I've ever played, its certainly skirting the line. The game is at odds with itself, not knowing what it wants to be. Is it an arcadey smash everything demolition derby game? Its too easy to be pinged out of your car and everything you crash into slows you down. Or is it a technical driving sim? Well it has boosting, very simple upgrading and far to slippery controls. What does this game want to be?

Ignore this and get FlatOut 2, they really improved EVERYTHING in the sequel.

To start: I used to add a much longer header to these reviews, but since it often made the reviews too long to submit, I've opted to leave it on my Backloggery. Also, wear your seatbelts, kids. This game should be the reason why you do.

Gameplay: I'm not too learned when it comes to racing games, but I do enjoy a good one from time to time. FlatOut is what I would consider to be a good racing game. Not a great one, but a good one at least. As you may or may not know, FlatOut is a racing game more in the vein of rally-style courses than Formula One courses, where there is a great deal of emphasis on vehicle control in rough terrain as opposed to hold down gas, turn wheel every once in a while. Yes, you will definitely need to make use of your brake button in this game, as well as maybe letting go of the gas every once in a while, as all the vehicles in game are rear-wheel drive. RWD means that you can do donuts. It also measn that you may find yourself doing donuts unintentionally. Since most racing games use front wheel drive, the physics in this game may feel unrealistic to some, but if you kinda know how a RWD car works, it's pretty solid actually.

The game has an alright selection of cars, but honestly, you should just pick the car with the best power-to-weight ratio just as a matter of principle. This game also has a system of currency where you win races to get more dosh, and while it never turned into a grindfest for me, it might be if you're not as decent at racing games. Plus, the vehicles with the best PWR aren't really too much more expensive than the ones of the same class. Yes, there are multiple classes of cars in the game, which unlock one class at a time over the three series. While you can beat class two racers with a class one car, it becomes very difficult, and in some instances downright impossible. The way that you can kinda do this is through upgrades, which while a neat idea is also not that well executed, as you have to buy components through a series of parts (you can't just buy the best parts on their own; you've gotta buy the crap ones first). These parts don't transfer to other cars either, which just makes the system feel like a waste of time.

The AI isn't exactly great, and if you've got an underperforming car, races can turn into an exercise in frustration as you have to take the track perfectly. There's no rubberbanding, which is good if you're absolutely smoking your opponents, but also pretty frustrating if you are way behind. AI in this game doesn't really have any aggression either; they just take the track as they want to, irrespective of you being in the way or not. This game manages to save a lot of file size by having only six maps where the tracks are different routes through the map. While the courses do for the most part feel their own (although there are a few lazy excuses for courses just being a course from earlier in reverse), you'll find yourself seeing a lot of familiar sights. Also, as mentioned earlier, this game is more along the lines of a rally racing game, so there's a LOT of start and stop. If that's not your thing, you may wanna look elsewhere.

Overall, while this game could've done with some more work on tracks and the AI, it's still a pretty fun game overall. I managed to 100% the game with all gold medals in the amount of time that I've been playing it (~8 hours as of writing this review), and I don't regret my time. I just wish there was a bit more done for the single player. 7/10.

Story: No story.

Graphics: The game looks pretty great for a game from 2004, and it manages to have a good bit of detail for only being a 1GB download. The maps are big and constructed pretty well, things break in a satisfying way, there's a good deal of detail to the cars, and it all just looks good. While a realistic style does have a tendency to age absolutely terribly, from the perspective of a game from 2004, it looks pretty damn solid. There's no optimization issues for modern hardware either, as I was able to run it at a perfect 60 FPS with everything on max at 1080p. One issue that cropped up every now and then was that a magical fairy would show up every now and then and make the HUD go away and vomit the alphabet at me. Fortunately, this can be fixed temporarily by just Alt-Tabbing, so it's not a huge deal. Overall, the game looks pretty great for a 2005 game and not half bad for today's standards. Give it 20 years time though, and it may not look so great. 4/5.

Sound: One big draw to this game for some is the amount of very obscure bands that this game has. Most of the bands are either of a punk or metal persuasion, but the metal only goes as far as something like a rip off band of Judas Priest. In fact, there's a few bands that sound like ripoff bands; there's a band that tries to be the Beastie Boys, one that tries to be every Industrial Band from the early 2000's, and one band that tries to be as terrible as possible (I still remember Killer Barbies' Baby With two Heads as being one of the worst songs I've ever heard from when I rented this game for PS2 back in '07). While it's not bad for the first few runthroughs and while there are still a few pretty good songs, it does get kinda tiresome after a few hours, so you're likely to just shut off the music and play your own. Sound design is delightfully chunky, and I still haven't gotten tired of the guy driver's derpy scream after being ejected from the car. Again, the problem with licensed music is that it's cool for a while, but it gets old really quick. 3/5.

Overall scores are: 7/0/4/3; cumulative score of 7.0/10. Pretty fun racing game, and definitely a fun one to play with friends, but apart from that there's not much to it.

Flatout is a fun and somewhat unique racing game. Rather than being a street racing game or track racing game like many other games of its time, the developers at Bugbear Entertainment decided to make a dirt rally racing game with some elements of destruction derbies.

There are 3 different divisions to race in; Bronze, Silver, and Gold. Each cup increases the difficulty slightly, all of which I still found fairly easy to get first in. When I first launched the game I chose to have the difficulty on Normal instead of Professional, so to anyone that plays this game I recommend selecting Professional. There are about 4 types of race tracks being Snow/Ice levels, Wooded levels, Construction levels, Town levels, and possibly another one (I can’t remember sorry :D). Each level type handles about the same as the next but with different aesthetics. The tracks can seem fairly repetitive because of this.

When you are driving down a track you can hit something hard and go flying out of your car. After a few seconds though you can reset your car back on the track and continue racing. This mechanic can sometimes be very frustrating because even if you are going super slow and hit the side of your car along a guard rail, you will sometimes be launched out of your car placing you behind the pack.

This game encourages you to knock stuff over and run into other racer’s cars, giving you the ability to use nitrous oxide which can boost yourself ahead of the other players. At the end of the race you will also be rewarded with extra cash for knocking things down like fences and street cones. There is an extra Bonus division where you can play mini-games like Darts by launching your driver at the dart board. While it does have silly mini-games like Darts, I prefer to play the destruction derbies.

If you have about $7 to spend and are into racing games, you should definitely check out Flatout.

For some reason, the initial game has a lot more variety than the 2nd one.

Of course there are flaws in the game. The soundtrack stucks at a single track for the race. The off-track sign doesn't let you go if you get back on track in like a meter from the place you went off. This also sucks, cause the level designs provoke you to try to cut corners way too much. The physics at a lower tiers are rather weird. You drift to much on literally every surface. That doesn't affect only race tracks. But as I mentioned before, heavy tier 3 car makes it even. There is no native widescreen support. An unofficial patch fixes it, but it bugs a bit. (Scratch that, patch works perfectly, it's the actual game that bugs with newer gpu drivers and it seems like there is no real fix for this issue.)

After all, I can see why this game is considered good and classic. What I can't see is how some call 2nd superior to the 1st one. Turning somewhat semi simulator into bunout clone ain't good at all.
